I looked at your report history. You report someone for feeding in LITERALLY every game you play.

Feeding is intentionally ruining the game for others by giving up kills in an effort to give the enemy an advantage, not having a bad game. I'm not entirely certain you are characterizing feeding correctly.

If you want the system to correctly identify your feeding reports, you need to stop reporting people for feeding who are not feeding.

everytime someone makes a thread about the report system a riot employee comes to commend that all reports have the same value.
realy makes you think
""If you want the system to correctly identify your feeding reports, you need to stop reporting people for feeding who are not feeding.""
https://media.tenor.com/images/4b7399689d7c8d618b7ea21bcec6be6d/tenor.gif

Don't read into it:-).

All reports have the same value and all trigger a review.

But if, as a community, you want feeders to be held accountable. It is in everyone's best interest to accurately report and make sure others do the same. It's hard to argue that the person you reported for feeding didn't get penalized when you report people for feeding who aren't. We do our best to create accurate models and detection methods, but it sure makes our job a lot harder when the signals are dirty. This is why intentional feeding is such a hard problem to solve.

The reason its hard to solve is because an automated system will never ever be able to determine if something is "intentional" or not. Until Riot is willing to have more manual reviews, or realize that it makes no difference if it is intentional or not, this problem will always exist. The most accurate and complex system in the World isn't going to catch someone inting if they are purposely trying to make it look unintentional.
If someone is unintentionally feeding, why would you want to punish them? What if you had a very bad game?

Because under the current system, having a "very bad game" and playing well in a loss are the exact same thing. I'm not saying feeders should be banned, but there absolutely should be some difference in LP/MMR loss.
Why?
Because as much as this community hates to admit it, personal performance matters.
In the short run that might be, but how exactly are you going to measure it without shifting the focus of players from winning to maximizing average gains?

It wouldn't be so much about maximizing your stats  because it would only apply to those "very bad games". I was only talking about in the case of feeders, and not people who are playing well but just trying to bolster their KDA.

So once you **have** one of those very bad games... what **then** prevents those people shifting their focus from at least maximizing their average gains?

You are, essentially, suggesting a system that will make people who already are having a bad game focus on their personal performance more than helping their team winning.

Or if you merely wish to reimburse those who are playing well... then you have an even bigger problem, because when non-feeding reasons are leading to a lopsided game, it's practically a good idea to lure people into supposedly even fights and pull out leaving the other person to die...
I mean hey, maybe they'll be bad enough so that I will ultimately lose less points.

>Absolutely. If someone is 0/15, they very well should be trying to fix that.

Okay, once a-fucking-gain:
HOW DO YOU ACTUALLY DO THAT?
Any kind of metric of individual performance that is not **directly** tied into the likelihood of winning is going to create scenarios where the smart (egoistic) thing to do, is **not** increasing the team's chance of winning.

Low amount of deaths is **not** a catch-all metric that is always bound to be positive for the team. Sacrifices can make sense. And not all sacrifices result in typically measured statistics... and even if they are, it's not a given that these statistics are considered as valuable as they were in that specific scenario.

> 
> Hah.

On average you will not lose the same amount, though, because on average the former stats will lead to more games won than the latter.
And that average will in the long term accurately reflect your personal contribution to the outcome of the games you have been playing.

Riot's metric is imprecise, but accurate.
What you suggest is more precise, but inaccurate.

And while that typically is a matter of preference, when it comes to ranking systems, any inaccuracy means that it can be exploited.
You are risking the integrity of the ranking system for the sake of smoothing out some of the short term fluctuations.

> [{quoted}](name=The Big Piece,realm=NA,application-id=ZGEFLEUQ,discussion-id=kidu4KER,comment-id=00020000000000000000000000020000000000000001000000000002,timestamp=2017-09-21T02:40:20.151+0000)

> 
> It shouldn't take 200+ games to determine someones deserved rank.

Whether the difference is 10, 1, or 10000 LP, you are shifting the average. You are shifting it away from the perfectly accurate "average contribution to wins/losses" to "average whatever-the-fuck metric you apply **plus** average contribution to wins/losses"

You still haven't answered btw whether you are fine with somebody who is 0/14 refusing to contribute in any meaningful way, because they are afraid to get that 15th death.

And regarding this bit:
>players would reach the rank they deserve more accurately and in less games.

**Please** read up the difference between accuracy and precision. Riot's system is perfectly accurate. And that's not an exaggerating or wrongly used word here... you **cannot** have a system more accurate than theirs, because what they are tracking will after "infinite" games average out to be precisely a metric of your personal chance to win a game under static conditions. This is, by any meaningful definition of the word, 100% accuracy.

Losing less LP/MMR would not effect the accuracy of your rank at all. You seem to be treating it as if you would not lose any LP/MMR at all. If we had a maximum of say +/- 10 LP based on performance, players would reach the rank they deserve more accurately and in less games. 

It shouldn't take 200+ games to determine someones deserved rank.

Yeah... Just that depending on the dedication towards not being caught the same can ultimately be said about manual reviews. Especially given that manual reviewers will have a much harder time comparing individual games with the same champion/role, and the likes, simply due to the time factor involved for humans.

Subtle trolls pose a problem for **every** system, manual or automatic, that aims for a high specificity.

Maybe they can eventually upgrade their system so that people who are 0/15 with multiple tears are banned quickly and consistently, but reports on the less obvious intentional feeders should not affect that as Tantrum claimed.

The maths been done. It would cost literally 10s of millions to hire people just to manually review games.

It's simply not possible.
